tweet: If you’ve contacted Congressman Young before, you know that this is not the type of reply you can expect to receive. Our offices get over 80,000 emails, letters, and calls from Alaskans each year and it's important we get it right when responding.

He may not have known it at the time, but his incredible story helped further the cause of civil rights, and secured him a well-deserved place in American history. May God bless the future sailors of the USS Doris Miller (CVN 81)!

His actions that day not only helped save lives, they also earned him commendation from Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox and the Navy Cross, which was presented to him personally by Admiral Chester Nimitz, commander of the Pacific Fleet. pic.twitter.com/k180zbHdri

Miller served in a segregated Navy and was prohibited from using guns simply because of his race. This didn’t stop him from springing into action and valiantly manning a Browning anti-aircraft machine gun until he ran out of ammunition during Japan’s attack on Pearl Harbor.

Tomorrow, the @USNavy will officially name a future Gerald R. Ford-class aircraft carrier after Pearl Harbor hero Mess Attendant 2nd Class Doris “Dorie” Miller, the first African American to receive the Navy Cross for valor. pic.twitter.com/saf1mxb4pQ
America stands with those fighting for freedom of worship around the world!

Still, it’s exactly what is happening to the persecuted Christians in the Middle East, the Rohingya Muslims facing genocide in China, and our Jewish friends and neighbors who have been threatened and harmed by anti-Semitism.
It’s hard to believe that in the year 2020, oppressive governments are still violating the fundamental religious rights of their citizens.
Today is #NationalReligiousFreedomDay – a chance to reaffirm our commitment to standing with those facing religious persecution across the globe. pic.twitter.com/cq83YXZMgu

Today, I spoke from the House Floor against a Democrat-led effort to turn back the progress we’ve made, both for Alaska and for American energy independence.

Many of my Democrat colleagues have never even stepped foot in our great state and yet have no problem trying to make decisions for Alaska. Opening up ANWR is a settled issue, and for a long time, ANWR exploration was also a bipartisan priority.

The State supports it. Alaskans support it. The Arctic Iñupiat who live there support it. And yet today, House Democrats are once again trying to shut down oil exploration in ANWR -- telling Alaskans how they should be using their land. pic.twitter.com/1l7VSezToT

It is my great hope that these trailblazers continue to inspire future generations of women and girls to pursue careers in science that will take our country to new heights.
This bill, which was signed into law yesterday, awards these pioneers the Congressional Gold Medal to finally recognize their contributions to computing, engineering, programming, and aeronautics.
For too long, racial and gender barriers prevented these women from being recognized for their achievements, which is why I was proud to cosponsor the Hidden Figures Congressional Gold Medal Act.
These women paved the way for generations of scientists and astronauts, and without their talents, @NASA may not be the impressive organization it is today.

Christine Darden, Mary Jackson, Katherine Johnson, and Dorothy Vaughan devoted their lives and careers to pushing our country forward in the fields of science and space exploration. pic.twitter.com/sEkLfTKLOv

BREAKING: House Dems tried today to close #ANWR for good, but they can’t stop the progress we’ve made. The ANWR Final EIS is complete, and we’re one step closer to harnessing AK’s vast resources and helping America lead the world in energy production:  https://bit.ly/2lNRXuK  pic.twitter.com/4eEGEoszne
Read my remarks against House Democrats’ anti-Alaska bill as prepared for the House Floor here: https://bit.ly/2lSGD0g

I am relieved that Alaskans have a Republican team in the Senate to protect our economy and land-use rights. Together, I’ll keep working with the Alaska Delegation to defend against the extreme partisan interests that seek to destroy jobs and opportunity within our state.

This bill passed the House but make no mistake: it will not pass the Senate; it will not become law; it will serve only the interests of environmental lawyers and the ultra-liberal politicians who support these disastrous policies.

The 1002 Area of #ANWR was specifically set aside by Congress for resource exploration. Every Governor, Senator, and Congressman from Alaska – Republican, Democrat, and Independent – have supported exploration in our state, but House Democrats simply aren’t listening.

Today, @HouseDemocrats passed a sham bill. It’s all political theater -- a show -- and they know it. These politicians don’t think we can take care of our own state. It’s time for Alaskans to be allowed to take care of Alaska. pic.twitter.com/vsapGyv67k

Curious about which unions and trade organizations lose out if the Democrats succeed in crushing American energy production? Click here:  https://donyoung.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=401411 … @NRDems

I'd like to remind @HouseDemocrats that national labor unions -- that Democrats claim to support -- oppose their efforts to close #ANWR. Their bill will destroy well-paying jobs and threaten thousands of blue-collar workers. I'm fighting to make sure ANWR is open for business. pic.twitter.com/vgXFVqSqGC
May God bless everyone lost on that fateful day, and may God bless America.

We were united with a sense of patriotism and community, and it is my great hope that we can honor those who were lost by recommitting ourselves to the values of unity, freedom, and service to our fellow Americans.
In the days that followed September 11th, the American spirit stood strong and resolute.
May we also remember the firefighters, police officers, other first responders and everyday citizens who risked their lives storming burning buildings – with many never to return.

18 years ago, America was attacked in an act of heinous terrorism, and thousands of innocent lives were tragically cut short. We must never forget the victims and their families, who continue to grieve to this day. pic.twitter.com/ZhNtYbPwXK

The State supports resource development in #ANWR. Alaskans support it. The Iñupiat who actually live there support it. Many of these Democrats haven't even been to Alaska, and we can't let them roll back progress on a settled issue.

The Iñupiat on the North Slope call the Arctic home, and I've been fighting for their right to benefit from resource development alongside them for years. This week, @HouseDemocrats will push a bill telling these indigenous communities what they can and cannot do. It's wrong.

Renewable energy is a key component of American energy independence, and Alaskans have my commitment that I’ll continue working to ensure that development in all forms is supported.
This bill was also signed into law, ensuring Alaska continues to have the resources available to expand renewable hydro projects. Read more about that legislation here: https://bit.ly/324iV1s
Additionally, I authored legislation to correct an error made by the federal gov't that was preventing 25 acres of land from being utilized for the Swan Lake Hydro Project in Southeast.

Last Congress, my legislation to expedite the expansion of the Terror Lake Hydro project on Kodiak Island was signed into law, saving the Kodiak Electric Assn millions of dollars that almost certainly would have been passed on to ratepayers. Read more: https://bit.ly/2sk0Eur

Southeast Alaska is rich with opportunities for hydropower. In fact, if these resources were fully utilized, Southeast wouldn’t need to burn another gallon of diesel fuel. I’ve long supported an all-of-the-above energy approach that includes renewables, such as hydropower.
As #NationalEnergyAwarenessMonth continues, I wanted to take a moment to highlight the various energy resources and projects around our state. pic.twitter.com/PX3X7QWSRa
